newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: INTERVIEW - Nokia sees Asia sales growing.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Nokia sees Asia sales growing.

text.p: Finnish telecommunications giant Nokia Oy is eying a 25 percent earnings contribution from Asia Pacific by next year compared to 22 percent in 1996, president and chief executive officer Jorma Ollila said on Thursday.

"Today, Asia Pacific is the fastest growing part of our business, generating 22 percent of the group's revenue in 1996. By 1998, we expect the share to grow to 25 percent," Ollila told Reuters in an interview.

For the quarter ended March 31, 1997 Nokia's pre-tax profit surged to 1.45 billion markka ($278.7 million) from 399 million int he same period of 1996, while sales grew to 11.33 billion from 7.93 billion.
Ollila said the region's growth, which had been evenly spread, would continue to be propelled by China, Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore.
While telecommunications infrastructure and mobile phone sales had been the growth engines for Nokia, Ollila said digitalisation in telecommunications would drive growth further.
"We are strong in digital mobile phones. Technology-wise, we are very strong in Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) and Digital Cellular System (DCS)," he said.
The group plans to increase investments in research and development (R&D) and expand its manufacturing in the region.
Ollila declined to reveal the investment budget or Nokia's investment commitment in the region to date, but said:
"If we have 25 percent of our sales from the region, we would look forward to having 25 percent of our investment in the area.".
Ollila said Nokia's growth would be organic and it had no plans to join any global alliance to spur growth.
"Nokia's growth has been through its own R&D and marketing capability with no broad global alliances. We intend to continue that way," he said.
"At the same time, we are looking at opportunities to complement that basic strategy with local or business units or corporation alliances to strengthen our position," he said.
But, he said, Nokia was not in any major discussions at the moment.
The company, awarded a Singapore $50 million supply contract for its GSM network by MobileOne of Singapore last year, looks forward to expand the network's capacity, Ollila said.
It was also looking to contribute, possibly in wireless multimedia projects in Singapore ONE, the government's plan to link the whole island on one high capacity telecommunications cable system.
The network is intended to deliver multimedia services like films, video-conferencing and the Internet to every Signapore home.
